title: How to Improve Your Emotional Intelligence

steps.title: Emotional intelligence (EQ) is the ability to recognize, understand, and manage your emotions.
steps.content: Emotional intelligence (EQ) is the ability to recognize, understand, and manage your emotions. It also involves being able to perceive and respond to the emotions of others. [3] X Research source These skills are essential for managing stressful situations, achieving personal or professional goals, and having successful relationships with the people around you. [4] X Research source Emotional intelligence is also called EQ, (emotional quotient) because it can be thought of as the emotional version of IQ (intelligence quotient). EQ isn’t a fixed trait—you can grow and develop it over time. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Emotional intelligence consists of 5 key components.
steps.content: Emotional intelligence consists of 5 key components. These components are self-awareness, self-control, self-motivation, empathy, and social skills. [6] X Research source Understanding these 5 components can help you improve your emotional intelligence. Self-awareness : The ability to identify and understand your own emotions and how they affect your life experiences. [7] X Research source Self-control : The ability to manage and regulate your own mood, emotions, impulses, and behaviors. [8] X Research source Self-motivation : The desire to seek out challenging new experiences and the ability to delay gratification in order to achieve your goals. [9] X Research source Empathy : The ability to sense other people’s emotions and imagine what they might be thinking or feeling. [10] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good Magazine Journal published by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center, which uses scientific research to promote happier living Go to source Social Skills : The set of abilities we use to communicate with, influence, and motivate the people around us. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Identify and make note of your emotional reactions throughout the day.
steps.content: Identify and make note of your emotional reactions throughout the day. The ability to recognize and name your own emotions is an important indicator of a high EQ. [12] X Expert Source Jennifer Butler, MSW Love & Empowerment Coach Expert Interview. 31 July 2020. Try starting a journal to keep track of your emotions and reflect on their causes. [13] X Research source This will help you practice the skill of identifying your feelings and connecting them to the events that triggered them, so you can better manage your emotions in the future. For example, say you’re at work and you get cut off during a meeting. What emotions arose when this happens, and how did you respond? Maybe you felt embarrassed, which led you to be quiet for the rest of the meeting. Or, maybe you felt angry and stomped out of the room. Writing about the emotion and its cause will help you identify your triggers so you can be prepared for them if they come up again. Reader Poll: We asked 144 wikiHow readers what strategy they find most effective for maintaining self-awareness in social situations, and 53% of them said regularly reflecting on the interaction afterward. [Take Poll] Writing about your emotions is a great way to do some self-reflection.

steps.title: Pay attention to your body.
steps.content: Pay attention to your body. Instead of ignoring the physical manifestations of your emotions, start listening to them. Our minds and bodies are not separate, and they affect each other deeply. You can raise your EQ by learning how to read physical cues that clue you into what emotions you're feeling. This essentially raises your self-awareness, which is a key component of EQ. For example: Stress might feel like a knot in your stomach, a tight chest, or quick breathing. [14] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Sadness might feel like teary eyes or fatigue. [15] X Research source Joy, pleasure or nervousness might feel like butterflies in your stomach, a racing heart or increased energy.

steps.title: Practice Mindfulness.
steps.content: Practice Mindfulness. Practicing mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment and being intensely aware of your thoughts, sensations, and surroundings. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This helps you become more aware of your emotions while fostering a non-judgmental attitude toward them, which can help you raise your EQ. [17] X Research source To get started with a mindful lifestyle, try practicing mindfulness meditation . Sit down in a quiet place and focus on the sensations you’re experiencing. Feel the flow of your breath, and let any thoughts that come up pass without judgment. [18] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Learn to manage your emotions.
steps.content: Learn to manage your emotions. Once you’re able to accurately recognize and name your own emotions, it’s important to work on regulating and controlling them in order to raise your EQ. [19] X Research source Some helpful tools for managing your emotions include performing breathing exercises , taking a pause, and reframing. Deep breathing exercises can help calm stress and anxiety in emotionally-charged situations. Start by taking a slow, deep breath through your nose, letting the air flow all the way down into your belly. Then, let the air flow out through your mouth, and repeat. You might find it helpful to mentally count to 5 as you breathe in and then count to 5 again as you exhale in order to keep a steady pace. [20] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Taking a pause in the middle of a conflict or argument can help you avoid any impulsive emotional reactions. If you start to feel the tension rising, step away from the situation to cool off. Reframing involves shifting your perspective to focus on the positive in a situation, rather than the negative, which can help you manage difficult emotions. [21] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source For example, if you’re feeling stressed about a new responsibility at work, try to think of it as an opportunity to learn and grow.

steps.title: Work on your willpower.
steps.content: Work on your willpower. Self-control is one of the five major components of emotional intelligence, and willpower is key to self-control. Willpower involves resisting short-term temptation and gratification in order to focus on long-term goals. Researchers suggest that willpower is like a muscle, which means that it can get stronger over time with consistent, healthy exercise. [22] X Trustworthy Source American Psychological Association Leading scientific and professional organization of licensed psychologists Go to source For example, if your goal is to build a better relationship with your parents, willpower would involve controlling the impulse to lash out over small, day-to-day annoyances in order to work toward this long-term goal. Practicing mindfulness, setting clear goals, and avoiding tempting situations are helpful ways to build more willpower. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Practice self-compassion.
steps.content: Practice self-compassion. Self-compassion involves recognizing when you’re struggling and being kind to yourself in those moments. [24] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source It has many benefits, like lowering levels of anxiety and depression and improving your overall well-being. [25] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Research also shows that self-compassionate people tend to be more compassionate and empathetic toward others, which is a key aspect of emotional intelligence. [26] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good Magazine Journal published by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center, which uses scientific research to promote happier living Go to source Try to treat yourself the way you would treat someone you love. Imagine your best friend going through what you’re going through. What kind words would you say to them? Now direct these words of compassion toward yourself. [27] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Build your empathy.
steps.content: Build your empathy. Empathy involves being able to recognize how other people are feeling and share in their emotions. [28] X Research source It’s essentially the ability to put yourself in another person’s shoes. Developing empathy is a surefire way to increase your emotional intelligence and improve your relationships with others. Here are some ways to cultivate it: When you see someone experience a strong emotion, ask yourself, “How would I react in the same situation?” Actively imagine how they must feel, and think about what might alleviate their hardship. Read more fiction. Studies show that reading literary fiction improves the ability to recognize and understand other people’s emotions. [29] X Research source This means that reading more may help increase your empathy.

steps.title: Work on your listening skills.
steps.content: Work on your listening skills. Truly listening to others while they speak helps you pick up on their emotions and respond to them, which is a key aspect of emotional intelligence. [30] X Research source Work on your active listening skills in order to be a good listener . Active listening skills include using engaged body language, summarizing and repeating what the other person said, asking thoughtful questions, and making sure you take equal turns talking. [31] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good in Action An initiative by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center promoting science-based practices for a meaningful life Go to source Examples of engaged body language include making eye contact, facing the person you’re talking to, nodding your head, and reacting with animated facial expressions. [32] X Trustworthy Source Greater Good in Action An initiative by UC Berkeley's Greater Good Science Center promoting science-based practices for a meaningful life Go to source Try incorporating details from what the other person has said into your response. [33] X Research source This shows that you’ve been paying attention to what they’ve said. For example: “It sounds like you were frustrated because your sister didn’t make it to your birthday party. Did you guys end up working things out?” “So what happened after you left the grocery store? Were you able to find what you needed for the recipe somewhere else?” “It’s so wild that you ran into your friend from high school. Did you have a good time catching up?”

steps.title: Put yourself out there socially.
steps.content: Put yourself out there socially. Getting out of your comfort zone and making an effort to be more social can help you practice and hone your social skills. This is key to building more emotional intelligence. Social connection also leads to better emotional and physical health and promotes well-being. [34] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source If you tend to be more introverted, challenge yourself to accept invitations to social outings that you might typically decline. It can be scary to step outside your comfort zone, but increased social connection can have a positive impact on your life, from less stress and anxiety to better quality sleep. [35] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source
